Award.AbstractNarration:
The narrow goal of this project is to document how exporters and potential exporters in a small open economy respond to exchange rate changes. The project will explore firms' responses both in terms of pricing of home sales versus exports, and in terms of participation and sales in domestic and export markets. The project will make use of a unique proprietary data set that merges the plant census for Ireland (a small open economy) with the survey of prices used to construct the producer price index. The first stage of the project involves merging and cleaning the data. The second stage of the project investigates the extent and nature of pricing-to-market and the significance of price stickiness among a particular group of exporters. Preliminary results are suggestive of slow passthrough of exchange rate changes into import prices. Given evidence of more rapid passthrough at higher levels of aggregation, this suggests that entry and exit of products and exporters may be crucial to understanding real exchange rate movements. The third stage of the project investigates the response of participation and sales in home and export markets to movements in exchange rates.
Intellectual merit: The novelty of this project lies in the unique features of the data set. For the purpose of identifying pricing-to-market and pricing behavior, we know that the products we focus on are actually traded, rather than potentially traded. We measure prices in home and export markets from the producer’s perspective, and we can be certain that we are comparing prices for products produced in the same plant. This gives us a clean identification strategy. Relative to other work on entry, exit and quantity responses of exporters to exchange rate changes, we have access to panel data on sales to some export destinations for the full population of plants rather than just a sample of larger plants.
Broader impacts: The broader objective of the project is to understand the microeconomic interactions that underly the behavior of real exchange rates at the macro level. The results of the project described here will contribute to our understanding of passthrough of exchange rate changes into import prices and the simultaneous dynamics of import behavior, which form an important transmission channel of monetary and exchange rate policy. The project at hand does not focus on the US, but on the case of exporters in a small open economy (Ireland) exporting to a bigger economy (the UK). This case is particularly relevant to understanding why depreciation of the dollar has seemed to have little impact on import prices and overall imports in recent times, because the competitive position of foreign firms selling in the US market is likely to be very comparable to that of the firms in the data

POR.DRECONTENT:
The exchange rate is a key relative price in open economies. It is simultaneously both the outcome of, and a determinant of the relative economic position of different countries. For example, the recent Brexit vote in the UK was followed by a substantial (and so far sustained) depreciation of Sterling against the currencies of the UK’s major trading partners. Because the behavior of real exchange rates has long been considered a puzzle that cannot be explained by simple models of firm behavior, the degree to which this will affect British importers and exporters, and the speed with which this will happen is a matter of debate among policy makers and economists. This project uses very rich micro data to document how firms respond to exchange rates, with the long-term goal of providing a building block in a better macroeconomic model of exchange rates.

 

The first paper in this project (“Pricing-to-Market: Evidence from Plant-Level Prices”) documents price responses to exchange rates at the plant level. It makes use of a unique data set that reports on a monthly basis the prices that a sample of individual Irish manufacturing plants charge for the same products in the Irish and UK markets. We first confirm that prices are sticky in the currency of invoicing. So when prices are invoiced in local currency (Euros in Ireland, Pounds Sterling in the UK), the default is that the relative price across the two markets moves one-for-one with the nominal exchange rate between the Euro and Sterling. We then show that both the timing and magnitude of price changes in Ireland and the UK are independent of movements in the nominal exchange rate. As a result, even conditional on changing prices, producers invoicing in local currency do not adjust relative prices across these two markets in order to reduce deviations brought about by movements in exchange rates. This strongly implies that producers allow profit margins to move systematically in response to movements in exchange rates. In contrast, producers invoicing in Euros in both the home and foreign markets maintain constant relative prices in pairs of markets, both by default, and conditional on changing prices.

 

The above analysis focuses on prices, and does not document the associated behavior of quantities. In “Exporters and Shocks: Dissecting the International Elasticity Puzzle,” we turn to customs data on exports in order to do this. The customs data we use reports for Irish manufacturing firms the value of their exports in all the markets (countries) they sell to. Using this data, we show that at the level of the firm and the export market, export participation is unresponsive to real exchange rates (and to nominal exchange rates, which are the major source of variation in real exchange rates). Moreover, export sales conditional on export participation are also unresponsive to real exchanges. However both export participation and export sales do respond to changes in relative prices across destination markets that arise from changes in tariffs.

 

The next step in the project is to build a new model of the firm’s decision problem. In “How Exporters Grow” we use the customs micro data for Ireland to document the steady state dynamics of how export quantities and prices evolve after entry to an export market. We show that export prices and export quantities are not always tightly linked. After export entry, there are economically and statistically significant dynamics of quantities, but no dynamics of prices. These facts strongly suggest the presence of costs of adjusting quantities in export markets. In particular, the behavior of quantities and prices suggest that these costs arise from the slow process of learning about latent demand for a firm’s product in a new market, and building up customer base that market. Economists working with micro data on prices have presented extensive evidence that prices are sticky. In this paper, we show that not just prices, but also quantities can be sticky.

 

Finally, in ongoing work, provisionally titled “Costs of Adjustment and Exporter Behavior,” we test whether the model with sticky quantities can explain the responses of prices and export values to exchange rates at the firm level. We also examine its performance relative to more standard sticky price models. If successful, the sticky quantity model could be an important building block in a better macroeconomic model of exchange rates.
